results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: A licence to open

details.description:
17th January lecture... A licence to open
Examining the key role of licences and contracts in achieving open software, data, medicine and hardware.
details.excerpt: For our 17th January lecture… A licence to open.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: An Open Data Christmas

details.excerpt: Ending 2013 with a sparkle, we asked three Friday lunchtime lecturers - David Tarrant, Jeni Tennison and Patrick Hussey - to return and tell us their version or vision of an Open Data Christmas.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: Burn the digital paper! A call to arms

details.description: Friday lunchtime lectures at the Open Data Institute - you bring your lunch, we provide tea & coffee, an interesting talk, and enough time to get back to your desk.
details.excerpt: Nearly 70 years of computers, and most of us still just use them as a fast version of paper. What is code? What is data? Teaching everyone to program, restructuring organisations … artificial intelligence. What will it take to make “data” ten times better?

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: Can open data improve government procurement?

details.description: Friday lunchtime lecture: Can open data improve government procurement?
details.excerpt: Friday lunchtime lectures at the Open Data Institute. You bring your lunch, we provide tea & coffee, an interesting talk, and enough time to get back to your desk.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: Five lessons from a decade working with open data

details.excerpt: In a decade of running data-heavy civic tech sites such as FixMyStreet, TheyWorkForYou and Mapumental, mySociety has learned a lot about how to gather, display, and archive data - and we have the yarns to prove it.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: How politicians lie with data

details.description: You bring your lunch, we provide tea & coffee, an interesting talk, and enough time to get back to your desk.
details.excerpt: Politicians are often criticised for their liberal use of statistics and data, and 2013 has been no exception. Hetan Shah, executive director of the Royal Statistical Society, examined how politicians lie with data and what we can do about it.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: How to build an open data centric organisation

details.description: Since March 2012 Land Registry has been releasing free datasets to support the government’s economic growth, open data and transparency agendas. Hear the data journey of the authoritative source for land and property data and where it’s ambition lies.
details.excerpt: Since March 2012 Land Registry has been releasing free datasets to support the UK government’s economic growth, open data and transparency agendas. Understand the data journey of the authoritative source for land and property data and where it’s ambition lies with the Land Registry’s Andrew Trigg, George Davies and Ben White.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: Typhoon Crisis Mapping with OpenStreetMap

details.description: An introduction to OpenStreetMap, the UK-born project to map the world as open data, and a look at how volunteer mappers helped with disaster response in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan.
details.excerpt: Founded in the UK in 2004, inspired by the success of Wikipedia and crowd sourcing information, OpenStreetMap aims to map the world as open data.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: What open data do we need for a cleaner, greener world?

details.description: Climate change is global, yet solving the challenges are often local and bound up in policy making, industrial, organisational and personal decision making.
details.excerpt: Friday lunchtime lectures at the Open Data Institute. You bring your lunch, we provide tea & coffee, an interesting talk, and enough time to get back to your desk.

results.title: Friday lunchtime lecture: What's the point of cultural open data?

details.description: Friday lunchtime lectures at the Open Data Institute - you bring your lunch, we provide tea & coffee, an interesting talk, and enough time to get back to your desk.
details.excerpt: Open data from arts and cultural organisations won’t help you choose a school or a hospital or make a financial decision, but it could create new ways of understanding history, experiencing great art and literature, and - fundamentally - help us to understand more about ourselves.
